channel.title: Homes on Manoshi Sen Datta
channel.description: Recent content in Homes on Manoshi Sen Datta

item.description: About me I am a microbial ecologist working with Roy Kishony in the Faculty of Biology at the Technion. I am strongly motivated by the dream of designing and engineering microbial communities in the human body to treat infectious diseases. To this end, I am working towards the following long-term goals: Community assembly: Characterizing the complex dynamical processes by which microbes form structured communities in the human body Community evolution: Predicting how human-associated microbial communities evolve in response to environmental change, including treatment with antibiotics Community spatial structure: Developing novel tools to interrogate microbial communities in the human body at the scale of a cellular “neighborhood” I completed my Ph.

item.title: News
item.description: June 6, 2018: How does copepod host physiology shape their associated bacterial communities? We explore this question in our new paper, Inter-individual variability in copepod microbiomes reveals bacterial networks linked to host physiology. May 4, 2018: Nate, Arolyn, and I put our new paper, Rapid, inexpensive measurement of synthetic bacterial community composition by Sanger sequencing, on bioRxiv! March 26, 2018: I was awarded an HFSP Long-Term Fellowship! I’m excited to have the opportunity to pursue my interests in microbial community evolution on the human body.
